org.lname: Autism Speaks U - NYIT Old Westbury

org.description:
Executive Board:

President: Brent Thomas

The American Medical Student Association (AMSA), with a half-century history of medical student activism, is the oldest and largest independent association of physicians-in-training in the United States. Today, AMSA is a student-governed, national organization committed to representing the concerns of physicians-in-training. AMSA members are medical students, premedical students, interns, residents and practicing physicians. Founded in 1950, AMSA continues its commitment to improving medical training and the nation's health. How is AMSA different from other organizations? When you join AMSA, you become part of a vital force of future physicians who believe that patients and health professionals are partners in the management of health care and that access to high-quality health care is a right and not a privilege. At AMSA, activism is a way of life. Student idealism is transformed into meaningful public service, innovation and institutional change.

An academic interest club that promotes behavioral science and psychology majors.

Executive Board:

Vice President: Stephen Owens

Secretary: Amrin Amlani

Treasurer: Sehar Iqbal

Meeting Times: Thursdays during Free Hour(12:30-2:00) in room 308

Our club's focus is to help guide students who are interested in working in some type of occupation in the health field. Whether its a student studying to become a doctor, physical therapist, nurse, and many more. Our club is more focused on networking and helping students get the resources they need to help them along their paths. Whether its finding internships, books, jobs, mentors, volunteering, and much more.

Executive Board:

President: Rachana Patel

Vice President: Jinu Thomas

Secretary: Shivani Nagpal

Treasurer: Josselyn Jose

Public Relations: Angelica Manzolillo

NYIT Dhadkan is a fusion dance team that strives to preserve Bollywood dancing. Dhadkan is a fresh and exciting dance troupe that represents talent, passion, and creativity. The dancers incorporate various other dance styles in their performances, such as Hip Hop, Classical, Contemporary and Bhangra. We welcome all styles of dance. In addition, NYIT competes nationally & locally within New York.

Executive Board:

President: Hera Jafri

Vice President: Rachel Patel

Secretary: Sehar Iqbal

Treasurer: Akash Patel

Event Coordinator: Rajeev Dalal

Liason: Siddhant Kulkarni

G.I.V.E. was founded in the summer of 2008 at the University of Virginia. The idea originated from a group of college students who were discussing the lack of positive influences for teenagers living in disadvantaged neighborhoods. We decided the best way to take action was by creating an organization that was devoted to promoting college awareness in these neighborhoods. Our objective is to bring college students to underperforming high schools where they would give presentations and arrange local college visits for high schools students. In more recent events, we have evolved in doing fundraising for the Boys and Girls Club of Hicksville due to the fact that the state cut off their funding. We also plan to take part in their tutoring program, and even take part in some events from the organization, Big Brothers Big Sisters. We are also taking a part in the STEP Program, in which we talk to juniors and seniors in high school about the transition to college. We hope to inspire students to attend college and also work hard to graduate and create a bright future.

org.lname: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
org.description:
Executive Board:

President: Richard Mortimore

Vice President: Hurneet Singh

Secretary: Matthew Wighton

Treasurer: Nicholas Corso-Passaro

Meeting Times: Tuesday/Thursday during Free Hour(12:30-2:00) in room B16.

The IEEE student chapter at NYIT Old Westbury has evolved into one of the most well-known clubs on campus in the past few years. They have been very successful in their VEX Robotics Competition as well as many other projects they are working on. This past year students have worked on robotics projects such as LEGO Mindstorms, Johhny 5, and the VEX Robotics competition. IEEE members have also created a Beowulf Computer Cluster, a collection of common computers that share resources to make a high performance parallel computing cluster. Another project that is going on this year is the construction of a hard surface touchscreen computer. Once complete it will appear to be a large box with a touchscreen on the top. The computer will run Windows 8 and IEEE members will be developing applications for the computer.

The projects that the IEEE work on throughout the year give engineering students a way to experience practical and interesting applications of engineering concepts that they would not learn until later in their education. By doing this the IEEE strives to increase retention among engineering students. The IEEE also does projects for Festival of Lights, Relay for Life, and other events on campus throughout the year.

Executive Board:

President: Alvaro Jorge Guerrero Uribe

Vice President: Samprada Shrestha

Secretary: Aditya Deshmankar

Treasurer: Taylor Geer Maupin

We, the members of International Students Association, hereby associate ourselves to help students from the beginning, when they are adapting to a new culture and new environment; until the end when you want to get a job, internship and more importantly when you graduate.

Executive Board:

President: Don Jeudi

Vice President: Juan Adelson

Secretary: Thulani Ngazimbi

Treasurer: Evan Sampson

The mission of the National Society of Black Engineers is "to increase the number of culturally responsible Black Engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally and positively impact the community." The National Society of Black Engineers strives to accomplish the following objectives for our organization: Stimulate and develop student interest in the various engineering disciplines Strive to increase the number of minority students studying engineering at both the undergraduate and graduate levels Encourage members to seek advanced degrees in engineering or related fields and to obtain professional engineering registrations Promote public awareness of engineering and the opportunities for minorities in that profession Function as a representative body on issues and developments that affect the careers of minorities involved in S.T.E.M fields

Meeting times: Tuesday/Thursday, free hour, B26 or theobald hall 409

The South Asian Student Association of the New York Institute of Technology is a student organization aimed at spreading South Asian Culture to both the NYIT community and the greater New York area. We promote South Asian Culture through a number of events that range from lively social events to enlightening cultural shows. SASA heavily relies on the student body to help achieve the goal of spreading South Asian cultural awareness. Consequently, we actively encourage student of all ethnicities to help us foster a wider understanding of South Asian Culture.
